content.body: haiii. is this step missing an explicit return statement? since state machine would not move after it
oh, sorry, it'll just check the next character with the same state

Are there general principles for how the `input` element is meant to behave in terms of user-entered values, `.value` values, and submitted values? Notably, the spec text for `email` very much goes in the direction of non-Punycode forms of the domain being an UI presentation issue only. Dates and times clearly are supposed to submit in the ISO format. Yet, `url` seems to submit what the user entered instead of submitting serialization after URL parsing.
content.formatted_body: Are there general principles for how the input element is meant to behave in terms of user-entered values, .value values, and submitted values? Notably, the spec text for email very much goes in the direction of non-Punycode forms of the domain being an UI presentation issue only. Dates and times clearly are supposed to submit in the ISO format. Yet, url seems to submit what the user entered instead of submitting serialization after URL parsing.

content.body: hsivonen: I think the more we can move towards submitting and exposing (to script) a normalized form, the better
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: I think the more we can move towards submitting and exposing (to script) a normalized form, the better

content.body: Looks like in Chrome setting email value via JS doesn't immediately normalize the value, but attempting to submit still catches a prohibited value.
When editing email manually (not via JS), if the entered value is failing constraint validation, the `.value` is unnormalized. If the value passes constraint validation, the `.value` is normalized.
content.formatted_body: When editing email manually (not via JS), if the entered value is failing constraint validation, the .value is unnormalized. If the value passes constraint validation, the .value is normalized.

content.body: Sigh. Chrome uses UTS 46 transitional=true for `input type=email` despite using transitional=false for URL handling.
content.formatted_body: Sigh. Chrome uses UTS 46 transitional=true for input type=email despite using transitional=false for URL handling.

content.body: Yeah, I wouldn't want to enshrine what is shipped today and I think we have some room for changes here.
I tried to be as brief as I could while still covering all the points, and I still ended up with a megacomment: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/4562#issuecomment-2084725431
(I think we need to list the questions that need answering, because without specific questions that issue doesn't appear to be converging.)
Thanks for writing that Henri. Hopefully you're more successful in getting people to make constructive comments in that issue.

Hi! Is there an official site for the latest updates of the HTML standard? Or how do I find out the latest changes that are being included in the HTML living standard? Please don't tell me to read GitHub commits because it's not a good idea. I'm looking for a site that tells me something like this: "24/4: the following changes were added..." Thanks

> <@christianmx:matrix.org> Hi! Is there an official site for the latest updates of the HTML standard? Or how do I find out the latest changes that are being included in the HTML living standard? Please don't tell me to read GitHub commits because it's not a good idea. I'm looking for a site that tells me something like this: "24/4: the following changes were added..." Thanks

There used to be a "Last Week in HTML..." blog post series, but that stopped being maintained years ago. Nowadays reading the commit history is indeed the only way to track things.
